\doxysubsection{Detailed Description}
Circular doubly linked list.

In computer science, a linked list is a linear collection of data elements, whose order is not given by their physical placement in memory. Instead, each element points to the next. It is a data structure consisting of a collection of nodes which together represent a sequence. In its most basic form, each node contains\+: data, and a reference (in other words, a link) to the next node in the sequence. This structure allows for efficient insertion or removal of elements from any position in the sequence during iteration. \mbox{[}\href{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked_list}{\texttt{ https\+://en.\+wikipedia.\+org/wiki/\+Linked\+\_\+list}}\mbox{]}

In a \textquotesingle{}doubly linked list\textquotesingle{}, each node contains, besides the next-\/node link, a second link field pointing to the \textquotesingle{}previous\textquotesingle{} node in the sequence. The two links may be called \textquotesingle{}forward(\textquotesingle{}s\textquotesingle{}) and \textquotesingle{}backwards\textquotesingle{}, or \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} and \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{}(\textquotesingle{}previous\textquotesingle{}). \mbox{[}\href{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked_list\#Doubly_linked_list}{\texttt{ https\+://en.\+wikipedia.\+org/wiki/\+Linked\+\_\+list\#\+Doubly\+\_\+linked\+\_\+list}}\mbox{]}

In the last node of a list, the link field often contains a null reference, a special value is used to indicate the lack of further nodes. A less common convention is to make it point to the first node of the list; in that case, the list is said to be \textquotesingle{}circular\textquotesingle{} or \textquotesingle{}circularly linked\textquotesingle{}; otherwise, it is said to be \textquotesingle{}open\textquotesingle{} or \textquotesingle{}linear\textquotesingle{}. It is a list where the last pointer points to the first node. \mbox{[}\href{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked_list\#Circular_linked_list}{\texttt{ https\+://en.\+wikipedia.\+org/wiki/\+Linked\+\_\+list\#\+Circular\+\_\+linked\+\_\+list}}\mbox{]}

In computer science, a linked list is a linear collection of data elements, whose order is not given by their physical placement in memory. Instead, each element points to the next. It is a data structure consisting of a collection of nodes which together represent a sequence. In its most basic form, each node contains\+: data, and a reference (in other words, a link) to the next node in the sequence. This structure allows for efficient insertion or removal of elements from any position in the sequence during iteration. \mbox{[}\href{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked_list}{\texttt{ https\+://en.\+wikipedia.\+org/wiki/\+Linked\+\_\+list}}\mbox{]}

In a \textquotesingle{}doubly linked list\textquotesingle{}, each node contains, besides the next-\/node link, a second link field pointing to the \textquotesingle{}previous\textquotesingle{} node in the sequence. The two links may be called \textquotesingle{}forward(\textquotesingle{}s\textquotesingle{}) and \textquotesingle{}backwards\textquotesingle{}, or \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} and \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{}(\textquotesingle{}previous\textquotesingle{}). \mbox{[}\href{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked_list\#Doubly_linked_list}{\texttt{ https\+://en.\+wikipedia.\+org/wiki/\+Linked\+\_\+list\#\+Doubly\+\_\+linked\+\_\+list}}\mbox{]}

In the last node of a list, the link field often contains a null reference, a special value is used to indicate the lack of further nodes. A less common convention is to make it point to the first node of the list; in that case, the list is said to be \textquotesingle{}circular\textquotesingle{} or \textquotesingle{}circularly linked\textquotesingle{}; otherwise, it is said to be \textquotesingle{}open\textquotesingle{} or \textquotesingle{}linear\textquotesingle{}. It is a list where the last pointer points to the first node. \mbox{[}\href{https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linked_list\#Circular_linked_list}{\texttt{ https\+://en.\+wikipedia.\+org/wiki/\+Linked\+\_\+list\#\+Circular\+\_\+linked\+\_\+list}}\mbox{]}

Comparison Singly Linked List vs. Doubly Linked List\+:

\tabulinesep=1mm
\begin{longtabu}spread 0pt [c]{*{2}{|X[-1]}|}
\hline
\PBS\centering \cellcolor{\tableheadbgcolor}\textbf{ Singly Linked List   }&\PBS\centering \cellcolor{\tableheadbgcolor}\textbf{ Doubly Linked List    }\\\cline{1-2}
\endfirsthead
\hline
\endfoot
\hline
\PBS\centering \cellcolor{\tableheadbgcolor}\textbf{ Singly Linked List   }&\PBS\centering \cellcolor{\tableheadbgcolor}\textbf{ Doubly Linked List    }\\\cline{1-2}
\endhead
Linked lists are not stored in contiguous location.   &Linked lists are not stored in contiguous location.    \\\cline{1-2}
Dynamic in size.   &Dynamic in size.    \\\cline{1-2}
Memory is allocated at run time (not necessarily true).   &Memory is allocated at run time (not necessarily true).    \\\cline{1-2}
Uses less memory than a doubly linked list.   &Uses more memory as it also stores the address of the previous node.    \\\cline{1-2}
Element accessing requires the traversal of whole linked list.   &Element accessing requires the traversal of whole linked list.    \\\cline{1-2}
Insertion and deletion operation is slower.   &Insertion and deletion operation is faster.   \\\cline{1-2}
\end{longtabu}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{dlist\_back}{dlist\_back}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \#define dlist\+\_\+back(\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{}]{dlist }\end{DoxyParamCaption})~(\mbox{\hyperlink{dlist_8h_a79b530d7d8bc62657ffb605744bbc497}{dlist\+\_\+prev}}(dlist,dlist))}



Returns the last node in a circular doubly linked list. 

This macro provides an iterator to the last node in a circular doubly linked list. It uses the {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+prev} macro to find the node that precedes the list node itself ({\ttfamily dlist}). In a circular doubly linked list, the \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{} pointer of the list node points to the last element, making this an efficient method to access the last node.

This is particularly useful for operations that require access to the end of the list, such as appending elements or performing operations in reverse order. It is important to note that if the list is empty, the macro will return the list node itself, which should not be treated as a valid data-\/containing node.

Usage\+:

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{dlist\_begin}{dlist\_begin}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \#define dlist\+\_\+begin(\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{}]{dlist }\end{DoxyParamCaption})~((dlist)-\/$>$next)}



Returns an iterator to the beginning of the list. 

This macro provides an iterator pointing to the first element in a circular doubly linked list. It returns the node immediately following the list node, which is considered the first element of the list. If the list is empty, this iterator will point back to the list node itself.

It is important to note that if the list is empty, the returned iterator should not be dereferenced, as it would point to the list node instead of a valid data node. Users should check whether the list is empty (e.\+g., using {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+empty}) before dereferencing the iterator.

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{dlist\_empty}{dlist\_empty}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \#define dlist\+\_\+empty(\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{}]{dlist }\end{DoxyParamCaption})~((dlist)-\/$>$next==(dlist))}



Tests whether a circular doubly linked list is empty. 

This macro checks if a circular doubly linked list is empty by comparing the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the list node ({\ttfamily dlist}) to the address of the list node itself. In an empty circular doubly linked list, the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} and \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{} pointers of the list node point to the list node itself. If the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer points to the list node, the list is empty. Otherwise, it contains at least one element.

This is a quick and efficient way to determine if the list has any elements without traversing the entire list. It is particularly useful for checking list state before performing operations that require the list to have elements.

Usage\+:

\mbox{\Hypertarget{dlist_8h_a6d3fcaf247e1020ca87d6cb65757a935}\label{dlist_8h_a6d3fcaf247e1020ca87d6cb65757a935}} 
\index{dlist.h@{dlist.h}!dlist\_end@{dlist\_end}}
\index{dlist\_end@{dlist\_end}!dlist.h@{dlist.h}}
\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{dlist\_end}{dlist\_end}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \#define dlist\+\_\+end(\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{}]{dlist }\end{DoxyParamCaption})~(dlist)}



Returns an iterator to the past-\/the-\/end element in a circular doubly linked list. 

This macro provides an iterator referring to the past-\/the-\/end element in a circular doubly linked list. The past-\/the-\/end element is a theoretical element that follows the last element in the list. It is not a valid element and thus shall not be dereferenced. This iterator is commonly used in combination with {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+begin} to specify a range that includes all the elements in the container.

In a circular doubly linked list, the successor of the last element is the list node itself, signifying the end of the list. Therefore, this macro returns the list node to represent the past-\/the-\/end element. It is particularly useful for loop conditions and iterator comparisons where a sentinel value is needed to represent the end of the list.

Usage\+: 
\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{\mbox{\hyperlink{structdlist__node__t}{dlist\_t}} mylist;}

\DoxyCodeLine{    \} \textcolor{keywordflow}{while}(0)}

Removes a specific node from a circular doubly linked list. 

This macro removes a specific node ({\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node}) from the circular doubly linked list. It achieves this by adjusting the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the node\textquotesingle{}s predecessor and the \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{} pointer of the node\textquotesingle{}s successor to bypass {\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node}, effectively removing it from the list.

This operation is efficient as it directly manipulates the pointers of the neighboring nodes, and does not require traversing the list. It is crucial to ensure that {\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node} is indeed a member of the list; removing a node that is not part of the list will result in undefined behavior.

Users should also handle memory management for the removed node if it was dynamically allocated. This macro only removes the node from the list structure; it does not free the memory associated with the node.

Usage\+:

Iterates through all elements in a circular doubly linked list. 

This macro sets up a loop that iterates from the first to the last element in a circular doubly linked list. It initializes the iterator to the first element in the list using {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+begin}, and then continues to iterate over each element until it reaches the end of the list, indicated by {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+end}. This macro is useful for performing operations on each element in the list, such as searching, modifying, or printing values.

The macro uses a for loop to traverse the list, making it easy to apply a block of code to each element. It is important to ensure that the list is properly initialized before using this macro to avoid undefined behavior.

The {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+front} macro is useful for accessing the first element of the list in a direct and concise way. However, users should verify that the list is not empty before attempting to use the returned iterator to access list data.

Initializes a circular doubly linked list. 

This macro is used to initialize a circular doubly linked list, setting it up as an empty list. In an empty list, both the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} and \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{} pointers of the list node point to the list node itself, creating a circular structure. Initializing the list in this way is crucial, as it ensures that the list is in a known state, preventing undefined behavior when performing other operations on the list.

Proper initialization of the list is essential before using any other list functions or function-\/like macros, as they rely on the list being correctly initialized to a circular structure.

Inserts an element after a specified node in a circular doubly linked list. 

This macro inserts a new node ({\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+insert}) into the circular doubly linked list immediately after a specified node ({\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node}). The insertion is achieved by adjusting the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} and \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{} pointers of {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+insert}, as well as the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of {\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node} and the \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{} pointer of the original successor of {\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node}.

This operation allows for efficient insertion in the list without needing to traverse it. It is crucial that both {\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node} and {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+insert} are valid pointers to nodes properly allocated. The macro assumes that {\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node} is a part of the list and {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+insert} is not yet in the list. Improper usage may lead to undefined behavior.

Users should ensure that {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+insert} is correctly initialized before using this macro, as it only handles the linking of the node into the list structure.

Usage\+:

Retrieves the next node in a circular doubly linked list. 

This macro provides an efficient way to access the successor of a given node ({\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node}) in a circular doubly linked list. It returns the node that immediately follows the specified node in the list. This is particularly useful for iterating over a circular doubly linked list, where each node is connected to both its predecessor and successor.

The macro assumes that {\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node} is not NULL and is a valid member of the list. If {\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node} is the last node in the list, {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+next} returns the list node itself, as the next node in the circular structure.

Macro to embed a list node in a structure for a circular doubly linked list. 

Add {\ttfamily DLIST\+\_\+\+NODE\+\_\+\+TYPE} as the first member of a structure to make it suitable for use as a node in a circular doubly linked list. This macro defines an embedded {\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structdlist__node__t}{dlist\+\_\+node\+\_\+t}}} structure, allowing any structure that includes it to be linked into a circular doubly linked list. The embedded {\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structdlist__node__t}{dlist\+\_\+node\+\_\+t}}} structure is named {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+node}, and it contains the necessary pointers to the next and previous nodes in the list.

This approach allows for the creation of nodes that can store additional data while still being compatible with circular doubly linked list operations.

Removes the last element from a circular doubly linked list. 

This macro removes the last element in the circular doubly linked list, effectively reducing the container\textquotesingle{}s size by one. The removal is done by adjusting the \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{} pointer of the list node ({\ttfamily dlist}) to point to the second-\/to-\/last node, and then setting the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of this new last node to point back to the list node. This effectively removes the original last node from the list.

The operation is efficient as it directly manipulates the pointers without needing to traverse the entire list. However, it is important to ensure that the list is not empty before calling this macro. If the list is empty (i.\+e., {\ttfamily dlist-\/$>$prev} is {\ttfamily dlist}), calling {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+pop\+\_\+back} will have no effect.

Users should also handle memory management for the removed node if it was dynamically allocated. This macro only removes the node from the list structure; it does not free the memory associated with the node.

Deletes the first node in a circular doubly linked list. 

This macro removes the first node of the circular doubly linked list. It does this by setting the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the list node ({\ttfamily dlist}) to point to the second node in the list, and then updating the \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{} pointer of the new first node to point back to the list node. This effectively removes the original first node from the list.

The operation is efficient as it directly manipulates the pointers without needing to traverse the list. However, it is important to ensure that the list is not empty before calling this macro. If the list is empty (i.\+e., {\ttfamily dlist-\/$>$next} is {\ttfamily dlist}), calling {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+pop\+\_\+front} will have no effect.

Users should also handle memory management for the removed node if it was dynamically allocated. This macro only removes the node from the list structure; it does not free the memory associated with the node.

{\footnotesize\ttfamily \#define dlist\+\_\+prev(\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{}]{dlist,  }\item[{}]{existing\+\_\+node }\end{DoxyParamCaption})~    (((\mbox{\hyperlink{structdlist__node__t}{dlist\+\_\+node\+\_\+t}}$\ast$)(existing\+\_\+node))-\/$>$prev)}



Retrieves the previous node in a circular doubly linked list. 

This macro is designed to access the predecessor of a given node ({\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node}) in a circular doubly linked list. It returns the node that immediately precedes the specified node in the list. This macro is particularly useful for reverse iteration over a circular doubly linked list, where each node is linked to both its next and previous nodes.

The macro assumes that {\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node} is not NULL and is a valid member of the list. If {\ttfamily existing\+\_\+node} is the first node in the list (after the list node), {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+prev} returns the list node itself, which is the predecessor in the circular structure of the list.

Inserts an element at the end of a circular doubly linked list. 

This macro inserts a new node ({\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add}) at the end of the circular doubly linked list, right after the current last node. The insertion is achieved by adjusting the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} and \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{} pointers of the new node, as well as the \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{} pointer of the list node and the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the original last node in the list.

This operation is efficient as it directly manipulates the pointers without needing to traverse the list. After insertion, the new node becomes the last element of the list. It is important to ensure that {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add} is properly allocated and initialized before using this macro. Additionally, the list must be correctly initialized for this macro to function as expected.

Inserts an element at the beginning of a circular doubly linked list. 

This macro inserts a new node ({\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add}) at the beginning of the circular doubly linked list, right before its current first element. The insertion is done by adjusting the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} and \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{} pointers of the node to add, as well as the \textquotesingle{}next\textquotesingle{} pointer of the list node and the \textquotesingle{}prev\textquotesingle{} pointer of the original first element of the list.

This operation is efficient as it does not require traversing the list and directly modifies the necessary pointers to insert the new node. After insertion, the new node becomes the first element of the list.

It is important to ensure that {\ttfamily node\+\_\+to\+\_\+add} is properly allocated and initialized before using this macro. Additionally, the list must be correctly initialized for this macro to function as expected.

\doxysubsection{Function Documentation}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{dlist\_find()}{dlist\_find()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structdlist__node__t}{dlist\+\_\+node\+\_\+t}}$\ast$ dlist\+\_\+find (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{dlist_8h_af95cb0e87f5c2fc68cda38f6b98c77b7}{dlist\+\_\+t}} $\ast$}]{dlist,  }\item[{void $\ast$}]{node }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Checks if a node is in the circular doubly linked list. 

This function iterates through the circular doubly linked list and checks if a specific node ({\ttfamily node}) is present in the list. It uses a linear search, comparing each node\textquotesingle{}s address with the address of the specified node. If the node is found, the function returns a pointer to that node; otherwise, it returns NULL.

The search is performed using the {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+foreach} macro, which iterates over each node in the list. This function is useful for verifying the presence of a node in the list before performing operations that depend on its existence in the list.

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
The function assumes that the list is properly initialized and the {\ttfamily node} pointer is valid. The function runs in linear time complexity, as it may need to traverse the entire list to find the node or determine its absence.
\end{DoxyNote}

\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{dlist\_size()}{dlist\_size()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily size\+\_\+t dlist\+\_\+size (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{\mbox{\hyperlink{dlist_8h_af95cb0e87f5c2fc68cda38f6b98c77b7}{dlist\+\_\+t}} $\ast$}]{dlist }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Counts the number of nodes in a circular doubly linked list. 

This function calculates and returns the number of elements (nodes) present in a circular doubly linked list, excluding the list node itself. It traverses the list starting from the first element after the list node and counts each node until it reaches the list node again.

This traversal makes use of the {\ttfamily dlist\+\_\+foreach} macro, which iterates over each node in the list. The function is useful for determining the size of the list for various operations such as allocation, serialization, or applying algorithms that depend on the number of elements.

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
The function assumes that the list is properly initialized. An uninitialized or improperly formed list might lead to undefined behavior. The function runs in linear time complexity, as it traverses each element of the list.
\end{DoxyNote}
